name: Collatz Conjecture (3n+1 Problem)
latex: \text{For any positive integer } n: \text{ if } n \text{ is even, divide by 2; if odd, multiply by 3 and add 1. Repeat. Always reaches 1.}
explanation: Lothar Collatz's 1937 conjecture is deceptively simple: Start with any positive integer. If it's even, divide by 2; if odd, multiply by 3 and add 1. Repeat. The conjecture states you'll always eventually reach 1. Despite being checked for numbers up to 2⁶⁸, no counterexample has been found, but no proof exists. Mathematician Paul Erdős said 'Mathematics may not be ready for such problems.' It's been called the simplest unsolved problem in mathematics.

examples.problem: Trace the Collatz sequence starting from 7
Why is this problem so difficult?
examples.solution: The sequence behavior is chaotic and unpredictable, making it hard to prove all numbers eventually reach 1
steps: Some numbers take many steps (27 takes 111 steps)
The sequence can grow very large before decreasing
No pattern has been found to predict behavior
It connects to deep questions in number theory
Erdős offered $500 for a solution (still unclaimed)

proof: Status: UNSOLVED. Verified computationally for numbers up to 2⁶⁸, but no general proof exists. The problem is considered extremely difficult despite its simple statement. Many mathematicians have attempted proofs, but none have been accepted.
